I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  for  the  Northern  Rural  Infrastructure 
Development Sector Project.1 
 
The  proposed  project  will  address  sector  constraints2 by  rehabilitating  existing  irrigation 
2. 
facilities  and,  where  appropriate,  developing  new  ones,  as  well  as  rehabilitating  and  upgrading 
rural  access  roads  from  district  centers  and  kumban  (village  cluster)  centers  to  villages.  To 
enhance  the  impact  of  subproject  investments,  the  project  will  support  (i)  technical  extension 
services  to  subproject  beneficiaries,  (ii)  producer  groups  to  coordinate  supplies  of  agricultural 
produce  to  markets  and/or  processors,  (iii)  contracted  agricultural  production  with  price 
incentives based on quality, and (iv) initiatives to secure tenure and access to land for sedentary 
agricultural  production  and  land  rezoning  to  protect  the  integrity  of  watersheds  and  reservoirs 
above  rehabilitated  irrigation  systems.  This  will  contribute  to  improving  agricultural  productivity, 
diversifying  crops,  and  commercializing  the  low-performing  agriculture  sector  in  the  northern 
region. These investments will be complemented by (i) institutional capacity building for national, 
provincial,  and  district  agencies  towards  a  sector  development  approach  and  (ii)  heightened 
awareness  of  gender  issues  and  the  participation  of  local  communities  in  designing  and 
efficiently implementing about 25 subprojects.3 The proposed project will be implemented in the 
four  northern  provinces  of  Bokeo,  Luang  Namtha,  Oudomxay,  and  Phongsaly,  which  have  a 
combined population of 760,000 people, a third of whom are considered poor. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The Lao PDR is steadily increasing its exposure to international markets and commercial 
opportunities and reducing its dependence on traditional subsistence agriculture and logging. Its 
commitment  to  free  trade  and  an  improved  transport  network  is  transforming  the  northern 
region’s  participation  in  the  market  economy,  albeit  from  a  low  baseline.  Its  abundant  land 
resources  and  high  agricultural  potential  have  recommended  the  Lao  PDR  to  neighboring 
countries  as  a  potential  supplier  of  agricultural  goods,  both  food  for  consumption  and  raw 
materials for agro-processing. The development of higher-capacity transport corridors linking the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  and  Thailand,  as  well  as  the  smaller  transport  routes  east  to  Viet 
Nam, have enabled the supply of agricultural produce from northern Lao PDR to its neighbors. 
 
4. 
A significant transport network of national and international routes has been developed. 
However, the coverage of rural access roads connecting these corridors is limited and generally 
of  poor  quality,  inflating  transport  costs  and  constraining  Lao  competitiveness  in  regional 
markets. The commercialization of agriculture is hampered not only by an underdeveloped rural 
road  network  but  also  by  the  limited  opportunities  to  intensify  agricultural  production,  the 
predominant  livelihood.  The  northern  region  is  still  dominated  by  subsistence  production  on 
lowland rain-fed and irrigated lands, as well as upland cropping on sloping lands, usually under 
some  form  of  shifting  cultivation.  In  2007,  60%  of  the  rice  area  of  75,000  hectares  in  the  four 
targeted provinces was planted in bunded paddies, of which only 3% were irrigated. Production

 2 

 

systems  use  traditional  varieties  and  few  inputs  because  of  limited  access  to  higher-yielding 
varieties,  irrigation,  or  other  production  inputs.  With  the  predominance  of  smallholder  and 
geographically  dispersed  subsistence  production,  value  addition  and  marketing  are  limited  to 
drying, packaging, and the small-scale production of items such as sauces and spices. The more 
suitable  agricultural  areas,  often  located  around  district  centers,  have  the  greatest  potential  for 
higher  agricultural  productivity,  production  surpluses,  and  increased  participation  in  the  market 
economy. 
 
The  proposed  project  is  to  be  implemented  in  four  northern  provinces  of  Bokeo,  Luang 
5. 
Namtha, Oudomxay, and Phongsaly, where the average poverty rate is 37%, significantly higher 
than the national average of 30%. Recent analysis indicated that poverty incidence has declined 
since 1995 from a rate above 55%. The analysis found the greatest gains were achieved where 
there are links to markets and infrastructure, and that poverty persists in remote northern upland 
areas  where  there  is  only  limited  road  access.  Moreover,  52%  of  the  residents  of  the  northern 
region  are  ethnic  minorities  who  have  little  opportunity  to  integrate  into  the  market  economy, 
which is an important cause of their high average poverty rate of 42%. The incidence of poverty 
among minorities is reported to have declined more slowly since 2005 than that of the dominant 
Lao–Thai. Poverty is a result of infrastructure deficit. 
 
6. 
The  proposed  project  will  enhance  rural  inhabitants’  access  to  and  participation  in  the 
market economy to improve food security and livelihoods. The focus will be on the incremental 
production of  commodities  for  which  the  Lao  PDR  has  a  comparative  advantage  in  the  region. 
Enhancing agricultural productivity on existing agricultural land is essential, as little suitable land 
exists for expanding agricultural area. While wet season rainfall is plentiful, it is highly seasonal, 
and  uncertainty  constrains  yields  and  limits  production  options.  Irrigation  holds  the  key  to 
removing  the  risk  associated  with  rain-fed  agriculture,  enhances  productivity,  and  provides 
options  for  diversifying  into  new  crops  with  more  potential  for  profit,  such  as  dry  season 
vegetables  and  melons.  Significant  potential  to  enhance  agricultural  productivity  exists  in 
rehabilitating  small  gravity  irrigation  systems  to  secure  water  supplies  at  the  end  of  the  wet 
season  and,  where  possible,  provide  for  dry  season  cropping  by  retaining  water  in  reservoirs. 
Potential exists to deliver more efficiently other yield-enhancing technological interventions. 
 
Generating production surpluses can contribute little to production if access to markets is 
7. 
constrained.  The  limited  and  unreliable  transport  network  and  constant  risk  of  landslides 
constrain market access and limit production options to nonperishable goods. An improved road 
network is a prerequisite to achieving market access for small, widely scattered production units. 
Moreover,  it  will  facilitate  private  investment in  value-addition  through  processing. A  system  by 
which  agricultural  products  are  aggregated,  stored,  handled,  processed,  and  delivered  to  the 
market is a relatively new concept in northern Lao PDR but is gaining currency, fuelled by strong 
interest in contract farming and foreign direct investment. 
 
8. 
The  proposed  project  will  address  the  two  fundamental  constraints  of  low  agricultural 
productivity and limited market access.4 It will do so through investments in (i) rural infrastructure 
for  irrigation  and  rural  access  roads  and  (ii)  initiatives  to  achieve  greater  commercialization  in 
agriculture by exploiting opportunities in the Lao PDR and neighboring countries. 
 

                                                 
4   A sector modality is proposed, as the Lao PDR has its Draft Strategy for Agricultural Development to 2020 to meet 
the priority development needs of the sector. It has the institutional capacity to implement this sector development 
plan, following experience in four previous sector development projects financed by ADB. The policies applicable to 
the agriculture sector are appropriate and will be improved through the proposed project. 

 Project  objectives  are  consistent  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  country 
9. 
partnership  strategy  for  the  Lao  PDR  and  its  focus  on  rural  infrastructure  as  a  means  of 
promoting pro-poor, sustainable growth through private sector development, regional integration, 
and  transforming  agriculture  from  its  subsistence  orientation  into  a  diversified  sector  by 
addressing  bottlenecks  to  agriculture  commercialization.  The  proposed  design  draws  on  the 
experience of recent rural development initiatives that ADB has financed, including the recently 
completed  Northern  Community  Managed  Irrigation  Sector  Project  and  other  development 
projects  implemented  in  northern  Lao  PDR.5 Recent  experiences  and  approaches  found  to  be 
successful in the Draft Sector Assistance Program Evaluation have guided the preparation of the 
design,  in  particular  the  need  for  advance  action  and  the  prescreening  of  eligible  subprojects. 
The proposed project is similarly consistent with the government’s sector development objectives 
as  presented  in  its  Draft  Strategy  for  Agricultural  Development  to  2020,  which  promotes  the 
expansion of market-oriented agricultural production in an environmentally sensitive manner. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

The  impact  will  be  improved  rural  household  incomes  in  the  four  northern  provinces  of 
10. 
Bokeo,  Luang  Namtha,  Oudomxay,  and  Phongsaly.  The  outcome  will be  increased  agricultural 
productivity in these project provinces. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

11. 
The  four  main  outputs  are  (i)  productivity-enhancing  rural  infrastructure  constructed 
and/or  rehabilitated;  (ii)  productivity-  and  impact-enhancing  initiatives  adopted;  (iii)  the  capacity 
of  national,  provincial,  and  district  agencies  strengthened  to  enable  a  sector  development 
approach; and (iv) the efficient and effective delivery of subprojects and project management. 
 
12. 
Output  1:  Productivity  and  production-enhancing  rural  infrastructure  constructed 
and/or  rehabilitated.  This  output  will  include  the  rehabilitation  and/or  construction  of  small  to 
medium-scale gravity irrigation systems6 and the rehabilitation and/or upgrading of rural access 
roads.7 Subprojects  have  been  identified  by  the  provinces  based  on  eligibility  criteria  and  will 
have  been  prescreened  before  grant  effectiveness  to  ensure  conformity  with  government  and 
ADB social and environmental safeguards. Subproject appraisal will ensure technical feasibility, 
economic viability, consistency with overall project objectives, and strict adherence to the social 
and  environmental  safeguards  of  the  government  and  ADB.  The  technical  specifications  of 
subprojects  will  be  scrutinized  and  approved  by  the  line  agency  responsible  with  support  from 
grant implementation consultants to ensure conformity with established design standards in the 
Lao  PDR.  Construction  contracts  will  specify  the  preferential  employment  of  local  women  and 
men from poor households with equal pay for equal work, prohibiting construction camps. Local 
labor  will  be  mobilized  through  community  mobilization  to  assist  in  detailed  design  through 
consultation,  the  construction  of  on-farm  tertiary  canals,  and  the  routine  operation  and 
maintenance of the infrastructure developed. 
 
13. 
Output  2:  Productivity-  and  impact-enhancing  initiatives  adopted.  This  output  will 
include initiatives to enhance the impact and sustainability of investments in rural infrastructure.

It is based on the extensive research carried out by ADB’s Independent Evaluation Department 
that  confirms  infrastructure  as  necessary  but  not  sufficient  for  socioeconomic  development. 8 
These investments will be identified in a participatory and gender-sensitive manner from a list of 
options 9  and  developed  with  stakeholders  and  beneficiaries.  They  will  be  closely  linked  to 
infrastructure  investments  and  included  in  the  investment  costs  for  each  subproject.  Specific 
items will be identified during feasibility studies and delivered through services contracted by the 
relevant  agency  or  competent  entity.  Capacity  building  will  be  an  integral  requirement  of  all 
activities  to ensure  that women  and  vulnerable  ethnic  groups  have  the  necessary  skills  to  fully 
participate in and benefit from these activities. 
 
14. 
Output  3:  Capacity  of  national,  provincial,  and  district  agencies  strengthened  to 
enable  a  sector  development  approach.  This  output  will  build  capacity  in  the  Ministry  of 
Agriculture  and  Forestry  (MAF)  and  the  implementation  capacity  of  staff  in  the  national  project 
management  office  (NPMO),  provincial  project  offices  (PPOs),  and  district  coordination  offices. 
National initiatives will support the government’s policy to establish a project management facility 
toward  implementing  a  sector  development  approach.  This  will  include  support  for  the  nascent 
monitoring  and  evaluation  section  in  MAF’s  Department  of  Planning  covering  technical support 
for  the  design  of  a  project  monitoring  and  information  system,  equipment  and  networking 
facilities to link with participating districts, and training in management planning and performance 
monitoring.  It  will  provide  resources  to  operate  a  system  for  monitoring  the  impact  of  the 
numerous development projects and programs currently under implementation.10 The project will 
provide resources to the National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute’s Policy Research 
Center to prepare studies to assist in policy development for the sector. In particular, the project 
will  support  policy  research  studies  related  to  (i)  external  demand  for  land  for  agricultural 
production  that  effectively  removes  land  from  traditional  shifting  cultivation,  (ii)  the  associated 
impact  on  the  livelihoods  of  smallholders,  and  (iii)  approval  mechanisms  for  private  investors 
who aim to  undertake commercial activities in the provinces that inhibit their ability to compete 
with similar enterprises in neighboring countries. In this regard, the proposed project will link with 
the ADB-financed Greater Mekong Subregion trade initiatives currently planned for Boten, on the 
border with the People’s Republic of China, that are intended to reform superfluous sanitary and 
phyto-sanitary constraints associated with border closure for trade in agricultural commodities.11 
 
To ensure the efficient and effective implementation of sector projects, NPMO, PPO, and 
15.

financial  management,  progress  reporting,  impact  monitoring,  social  and  environmental 
safeguards,  and  contract  management.  The  project  will  engage  existing  provincial  and  district 
personnel, strengthen their capacity, and familiarize them with ADB and government procedures 
to ensure the smooth implementation of this project and future sector development initiatives.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

All  subprojects  eligible  for  financing  under  the  project  will  be  prescreened  before  grant 
21. 
effectiveness  to  ensure  consistency  with  ADB  and  Lao  PDR  social  and  environmental 
safeguards. Irrigation systems will be simple water-management structures based on established 
designs  and  standards  developed  under  the  ADB-financed  Northern  Community  Managed 
Irrigation  Sector  Project  (footnote  5).  For  rural  access  roads,  rehabilitation  will  follow  existing 
alignments and improve surface drainage. Most alignments identified in subprojects proposed by 
participating  provinces  follow  relatively  flat  terrain,  reducing  the  requirement  for  complex  bank 
stabilization with extensive cut and fill. In view of the harsh climatic and topographic conditions 
and  budgetary  constraints  in  the  provinces,  priority  will  be  given  to  rehabilitating  those 
alignments  that  can  demonstrate  an  economic  net  benefit  from  sealed  surfaces  to  ensure  the 
sustainability of benefits and minimize maintenance requirements. Maintenance will be financed 
by  beneficiary  contributions  for  such  labor-intensive  tasks  as  trimming  vegetation  and  filling 
potholes, while grant funds will enable district and provincial authorities to use heavier equipment 
for  more  significant  repairs.  Resources  to  improve  rural  roads  will  target  the  most  critical 
obstacles to access. Improvements will follow existing alignments using Ministry of Public Works 
and  Transport  geometric  design  classes  as  appropriate.  Special  attention  will  focus  on  the 
design  of  sustainable  road  drainage  (surface,  side,  and  cross)  and  the  use  of  appropriate 
surfacing and paving options to carry projected traffic loads. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

22. 
Direct  benefits  from  rehabilitating  irrigation  and  rural  access  roads  are  increased 
agricultural  productivity  and  reduced  travel  costs  and  times.  Indirect  benefits  include  the 
diversification  of  sources  of  income  and  market-oriented  agricultural  outputs,  increased  value-
addition,  improved  access  to  health  and  education  services,  and  reduced  costs  for  agricultural 
inputs  and  household  commodities.  Together,  the  benefits  will  reduce  poverty  in  beneficiary 
communities. Subprojects will focus on enhancing market integration through rural infrastructure 
development  and  associated  investments  in  technical  extension  services,  strengthening 
producer  organizations,  and  improving  the  supply  of  inputs.  All  anticipated  benefits  are 
incremental compared with the without-project scenario, in which competition for agricultural land 
is expected to remain high, the social and environmental consequences of existing practices to 
intensify, and economic returns to worsen.14 
 
23. 
The  economic  analysis  of  the  Nam  Haad  Irrigation  Rehabilitation  Subproject  in  Bokeo 
indicates an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of 15.6% based on quantified benefits from 
increased agricultural productivity for wet season crops plus opportunities for increased cropping 
intensity with some dry season irrigation and quality enhancement through extension initiatives. 
It  is  estimated  that  annual  paddy  output  will  increase  from  360  tons  in  the  without-project 
scenario to 654 tons in the with-project scenario, generating an increment of 294 tons per year. 
Gross  economic  crop  production  value  will  increase  from  KN988  million  in  the  without-project 
scenario  to  KN1,749  million  in  the  with-project  scenario—an  increment  of  KN762  million  per 
year.  The  net  economic  value  of  crop  production  (i.e.,  net  of  all  material  and  labor  costs)  will 
increase  from  KN349  million  to  KN963  million  per  year—an  increment  of  KN614  million. 
Incremental  net  crop  financial  value  of  production  per  household  is  estimated  at  KN2.2  million 
per year, for an increase of 176%. The poor, or 45% of the beneficiary population, are expected 
to  get  an  increase  in  net  annual  crop  financial  value  of  KN1.1  million  per  household.  In

C. 

Governance 

24. 
All  procurement  to  be financed  by  the  ADB  grant  will  be  carried  out in  accordance  with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time).15 MAF shall ensure that 
all  accounts  administered  by  the  NPMO  and  PPOs  are  consolidated  and  audited  annually  by 
auditors  acceptable  to  ADB.  The  capacity-building  component  will  strengthen  the  capacity  of 
NPMO  and  PPO  staff  in  financial  management  procedures  to  allow  the  efficient  operation  of 
advance  accounts  and  reporting  of  financial  performance  to  the  government  and  ADB.  The 
implementation  of  the  project  will  be  consistent  with  the  government’s  requirement  for  national 
coordination.  Provincial  implementation  will  seek  the  involvement  of  district  and  lower 
administrative  units  and  communities  to  ensure  their  participation  in  monitoring  design  and 
construction, as was done under the successful Northern Community Managed Irrigation Sector 
Project (footnote 5). Coordination with other agencies will be achieved through their participation 
in  the  national  and  provincial  project  steering  committees  to  achieve  the  necessary  technical 
support. 
 
25. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  MAF.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary  measures 
are described in the project administration manual and will be posted on the project website. 
 
D. 

Poverty and Social 

26. 
The proposed project will be implemented in northern rural Lao PDR, where the average 
poverty  rate  is  37%.16 The  analysis  of  declines  in  poverty  rates  since  the  mid  1990s  show  the 
greatest  gains  achieved  where  there  are  links  to  markets  and  infrastructure,  with  poverty 
persisting  in  remote  upland  areas  of  the  north  that  lack  road  access.  Ethnicity  is  also  a 
determinant  of  poverty,  as  ethnic  minority  groups  have  poverty  rates  above  42%  and  have 
recorded a slower decline in the incidence of poverty since 2005 than that seen in the dominant 
Lao–Thai.  Most  subprojects  will  be  implemented  in  areas  where  ethnic  groups  constitute  a 
majority and where poverty tends to be more pervasive than the national average. Investments 
in irrigation rehabilitation will improve the incomes and food security of households and, through 
associated  initiatives,  provide  opportunities  for  women  and  men  to  build  their  capacity17.  The 
project  will  provide  resources  for  implementing  subproject  gender  action  plans  and  indigenous 
people’s  plans.  Women  and  children  will  benefit  from  reduced  time  spent  collecting  water.  As 
women  are  greatly  underrepresented  in  village  and  community  decision-making  institutions, 
there  will  be  specific  interventions  to  increase  their  involvement  in  producer  and  water  user 
groups.  Vulnerable  groups,  mainly  ethnic  minorities  and  households  headed  by  females,  will 
enjoy  preferential  opportunities  for  construction  employment.  Intensified  agricultural  activity  will 
increase  demand  for  labor.  Investments  in  rural  access  roads  will  improve  access  to  public 
services  and  options  for  commercial  enterprises  and  marketing.  Through  the  provision  of 
infrastructure  and  road  access,  the  proposed  project  is  anticipated  to  contribute  to  improved

E. 

Safeguards 

27. 
Resettlement.  Little  resettlement  is  anticipated  as  subprojects  will  rehabilitate  existing 
infrastructure and require insignificant land acquisition. Further, subprojects will be prescreened 
before grant effectiveness to ensure they do not entail significant resettlement.18 Only category B 
and  C  subprojects  will  be  eligible  for  financing  under  the  proposed  project.  Any  minor 
compensation  that  may  be  needed  will  be  provided  in  accordance  with  resettlement  plans 
prepared  for  each  subproject  based  on  the  guidelines  outlined  in  the  resettlement  framework 
agreed with the government19. The project is categorized as B for involuntary resettlement. 
 
28. 
Environmental.  Prescreening  aims  to  ensure  that  subprojects  considered  for  financing 
will not have significant negative environmental impacts and that minor impacts can be mitigated 
through the implementation of the subproject environmental management plans prepared as part 
of  each  initial  environmental  examination.20 In  the  case  of  rural  access  road  rehabilitation  and 
upgrading, subprojects are limited to existing alignments and will most likely involve limited cut 
and  fill,  minor  widening,  and  little  realignment.  For  irrigation  rehabilitation  and  development, 
feasibility studies will ensure that water off-take during the dry season allows sufficient flows to 
maintain  the  riparian  ecosystem  and  ensure  adequate  resources  for  downstream  users.  The 
introduction of land zoning in the catchment areas of reservoirs will minimize inappropriate land 
use  and  reduce  the  risk  of  siltation  while  assuring  dry  season  flows.  Environment  category  A 
subprojects will be ineligible for financing under the proposed project. Technical specialists will 
prepare  national  and  provincial  environmental  assessments  and  management  plans  for  each 
subproject. The project is categorized as B for environmental safeguard. 
 
29. 
Indigenous  peoples.  The  otherwise  dominant  Lao–Thai  ethnic  group  is  a  minority  in 
each  of  the four  target provinces, where  the main  ethnic  groups  are  Mon-Khmer  in  Bokeo and 
Oudomxay  and  Chine-Tibet  in  Luang  Namtha  and  Phongsaly.  The  principles  followed  in  all 
subproject  preparation  will  be  consultation,  inclusion,  and  preferential  access  to  employment 
opportunities for vulnerable ethnic minority groups. As with socioeconomic baseline surveys, all 
data  collected  will  be  disaggregated  by  ethno-linguistic  group,  age  (where  appropriate),  and 
gender to allow the monitoring and evaluation of beneficiary inclusion. The proposed project is 
category  B  for  indigenous  peoples  because  (i)  most  people  in  the  four  provinces  are  ethnic 
minorities who generally have higher poverty rates than the nationally dominant Lao–Thai group 
and  (ii)  impacts  are  expected  to  be  positive.  The  prescreening  of  subprojects  and  consultation 
processes  will  exclude  subprojects  that  would  disadvantage  any  groups.  Indigenous  peoples 
plans for each approved subproject will detail requirements for inclusion, benefit measuring, and 
monitoring21. The project is categorized as B for indigenous peoples.

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

31. 
The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the project 
administration manual and grant documents. 
 
32. 
The  government  has  agreed  with  ADB  on  certain  covenants  for  the  proposed  project, 
which  are  set  forth  in  the  grant  agreement,  including  the  implementation  of  subproject-specific 
gender action plans prepared under the overall principles of the project-wide gender action plan. 
 
33. 
Condition  for  grant  effectiveness.  The  government  shall  submit  to  ADB  for  approval 
the list of eligible subprojects prescreened in accordance with the criteria set forth in the project 
administration manual. 
 
34. 
Conditions  for  disbursement  to  individual  provinces.  All  participating  provinces, 
except Oudomxay, shall establish a PPO in their PAFO and appoint key staff including safeguard 
officers  along  with  other  administrative  staff.  In  Oudomxay,  a  provincial  coordinator  and  two 
technical staffers shall be appointed in the PAFO to coordinate the project activities. 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

35.

Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  grant  not

resources  for  the  Northern  Rural  Infrastructure  Development  Sector  Project,  on  terms  and 
conditions that  are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement 
presented to the Board.
